page.title: 10ECOLOGY
page.content: CHORLTON EES was occupied by Withington sewage works for over 100 years until 1972, when under 'Operation Eyesore' the old tanks were dismantled and landscaped. It is now part of the Mersey Valley Country Park. Over 130 different kinds of birds breed or visit there, including short-eared owls and yellow wagtails, with flocks of redwings and fieldfares in winter. There are full-time wardens who look after the 900 acre site. A policy of further landscaping includes planting alder and willow, and creating marshes. Some old hedges of ash, oak and hazel remain with wild jops also present.
